item.name: SQL Default Instance:Batch Requests per second
item.description: Number of command batches received per second. It is usually a good indicator of the load on SQL Server.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Blocked Processes
item.description: Number of users connected blocked on the MSSQL Server.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Buffer cache hit ratio
item.description: Indicates the percentage of pages found in the buffer cache without having to read from disk. The ratio is the total number of cache hits divided by the total number of cache lookups over the last few thousand page accesses.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Database Pages
item.description: How many database pages are currently being occupied in the data cache. How often the SQL server can perform a transaction without having to perform disk I/O.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Data File Size
item.description: Total size (in kilobytes) of all the data files.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Locks:Average Wait Time
item.description: The average amount of wait time (milliseconds) for each lock request that resulted in a wait.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Locks:Number of Deadlocks per second
item.description: If you see these happening then check with your DBA or application engineer because deadlocks are a SQL performance killer.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Locks:Waits per second
item.description: Measures how much time the database is having to wait to deliver its data because of other transactions locking tables.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Longest Running Transaction
item.description: The running time of the longest running transaction, in seconds

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Memory:Connection Memory
item.description: How much OS memory the SQL service connections are using.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Memory:Total Server Memory
item.description: How much OS memory the SQL service is using.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Number Users Connected
item.description: Shows how many concurrent connections are utilizing the SQL server itself. A sudden rise in these may point to a hung application that isn't properly closing connections. A .Net application SQL connection pool can often spike the connection count when a transaction has caused a large number of table locks.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Page Life Expectancy
item.description: The page life expectancy counter measures how long pages stay in the buffer cache in seconds. Low if under 300 for a some time.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:Processor:% sqlservr
item.description: % Processor Time is the percentage of elapsed time that all of the threads of this process used the processor to execute instructions.

item.name: SQL Default Instance:SQL Errors per second
item.description: Tracks severe errors that cause SQL Server to take the current database offline.

trigger.name: SQL Default Instance: Long running transaction: {ITEM.VALUE} seconds
trigger.description: Too many blocked processes on SQL Server, more than 10 over a 10 minutes period.

trigger.name: SQL Default Instance: Many Blocked Processes: {ITEM.VALUE}
trigger.description: Too many blocked processes i SQL Server, more than 10 over a 10 minutes period

trigger.name: SQL Default Instance: Number Failed Jobs
SQL Default Instance: Number of Deadlocks per second
SQL Default Instance: Page Life Expectancy low: {ITEM.VALUE}
